doc.title: TeXML: an XML vocabulary for TeX
doc.p: Thesis of the talk at the First International Conference of Open-Source Developers, Obninsk, Russia, 2004. Author: Oleg Paraschenko, Saint Petersburg.

blockquote.p: Abstract. The paper describes one of the methods of publishing XML documents through LaTeX. We propose to use TeXML, an intermediate presentation of TeX notation in an XML format.

sect.title: The need for TeXML
sect.p: TeXML[1] is an intermediate presentation of TeX notation in an XML format. TeXML simplifies creation of printable versions of documents when the following conditions are true:

ul.li: original documents are in XML format,
printable versions are being created by LaTeX, and
XSLT is the best language for XML transformations.

sect.p: There are several projects([2], [3], [4], [5]) that transform XML to LaTeX using XSLT. All of these projects have the same problem: XSLT is very inefficient when the result of an XSLT transformation is not XML.
This problem can be solved using an intermediate step. First, XSLT efficiently transforms XML into TeXML, and then a TeXML processor turns TeXML into the TeX format.

sect.title: Brief overview of TeXML
sect.p: An example to demonstrate the basic syntax of TeXML:
The main tasks of the processor:

ul.li: escaping of the TeX special characters (for example, escaping “<” to “\textless”),
unicode processing (for example, printing russian letter “d” as is or as “\cyrchar\cyrd{}”),
disjoining of ligatures (for example, replacing “---” by “-{}-{}-”), and
avoiding empty lines in TeX output.

sect.p: In addition to these essential transformations, TeXML also provides extended functionality.

ul.li: The TeXML language reflects the structured constructions of LaTeX such as environments or commands with parameters.
Automatic layout of TeX code into nice human-readable documents.

sect.title: TeXML benefits
sect.p: There are several projects that create LaTeX from XML using XSLT, for example: tbook[2], xsltml[3], dblatex[4], db2latex[5]. Usage of these projects demonstrates the following problems when generating the TeX fragment:

ul.li: space after a command name is missed (getting “\ittext” instead of “\it text”),
opening or closing brace is lost,

sect.p: These and some other problems do not appear when using TeXML.

sect.title: Other versions of TeXML
sect.p: During my search for a solution for XML publishing through LaTeX, I found that Douglas Lovell introduced[6] the TeXML approach in the year 1999, and there was even an implementation in Java. This project, TeXMLatté[7], was abandoned some time ago, but its specification survived. Our TeXML is heavely based on this specification.
There is also TeXMLapis[8], a Perl-processor of a subset of TeXML, but its functionality is limited.
